name: Awesome Oscilator (AO)
description: AO is generally used to affirm trends or to anticipate possible reversals.

name: Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average (KAMA)
description: This trend-following indicator can be used to identify the overall trend, time turning points and filter price movements.

name: Percentage Price Oscillator (PPO)
description: Momentum oscillator that measures the difference between two moving averages as a percentage of the larger moving average.

name: Percentage Volume Oscillator (PVO)
description: Momentum oscillator for volume. The PVO measures the difference between two volume-based moving averages as a percentage of the larger moving average.

name: Rate of Change (ROC)
description: momentum oscillator that measures the percent change in price from one period to the next. ROC signals include centerline crossovers, divergences and overbought-oversold readings.

name: Relative Strength Index (RSI)
description: Compares the magnitude of recent gains and losses over a specified time period to measure speed and change of price movements of a security. Overbought or oversold conditions.

name: Stochastic Oscillator (STOCH)
description: Presents the location of the closing price of a stock in relation to the high and low range of the price of a stock over a period of time, typically a 14-day period.

name: Stochastic RSI (STOCHRSI)
description: developed to take advantage of both momentum indicators in order to create a more sensitive indicator that is attuned to a specific security’s historical performance rather than a generalized analysis of price change.

name: True strength index (TSI)
description: Shows both trend direction and overbought/oversold conditions.

name: Ultimate Oscillator (UO)
description: momentum oscillator designed to capture momentum across three different timeframes.

name: Williams %R (WILLR)
description: Momentum indicator that is the inverse of the Fast Stochastic Oscillator. Reflects the level of the close relative to the highest high for the look-back period. Readings from 0 to -20 are considered overbought. Readings from -80 to -100 are considered oversold.

name: Accumulation Distribution Index (ADI)
description: Acting as leading indicator of price movements.

name: Chaikin Money Flow (CMF)
description: It measures the amount of Money Flow Volume over a specific period.

name: Ease of movement (EMV)
description: It relate an asset’s price change to its volume and is particularly useful for assessing the strength of a trend.

name: Force Index (FI)
description: It illustrates how strong the actual buying or selling pressure is. High positive values mean there is a strong rising trend, and low values signify a strong downward trend.

name: Money Flow Index (MFI)
description: Uses both price and volume to measure buying and selling pressure. It is positive when the typical price rises (buying pressure) and negative when the typical price declines (selling pressure). A ratio of positive and negative money flow is then plugged into an RSI formula to create an oscillator that moves between zero and one hundred.

name: Negative Volume Index (NVI)
description: NVI integrates volume and price to graphically show how price movements are affected by down volume days.

name: On-balance volume (OBV)
description: It relates price and volume in the stock market. OBV is based on a cumulative total volume.

name: Volume-price trend (VPT)
description: The volume price trend (VPT) indicator helps determine a security’s price direction and strength of price change.

name: Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP)
description: It's the average price a security has traded at throughout the day, based on both volume and price. VWAP is important because it provides traders with insight into both the price trend and value of a security. consider stocks with prices below VWAP as undervalued and those with prices above it as overvalued. If prices below VWAP move above it, traders may go long on the stock. If prices above VWAP move below it, they may sell their positions or initiate short positions.

name: Average True Range (ATR)
description: The indicator provide an indication of the degree of price volatility. Strong moves, in either direction, are often accompanied by large ranges, or large True Ranges.

name: Aroon Indicator (AI)
description: Identify when trends are likely to change direction (downtrend/uptrend).

name: Detrended Price Oscillator (DPO)
description: Is an indicator designed to remove trend from price and make it easier to identify cycles.

name: Ichimoku Kinkō Hyō (Ichimoku)
description: It identifies the trend and look for potential signals within that trend.

name: KST Oscillator (KST)
params_names: (roc1, roc2, roc3, roc4, window1, window2, window3, window4, nsig)
description: It is useful to identify major stock market cycle junctures because its formula is weighed to be more greatly influenced by the longer and more dominant time spans, in order to better reflect the primary swings of stock market cycle.

name: Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD)
description: Is a trend-following momentum indicator that shows the relationship between two moving averages of prices.

name: Mass Index (MI)
description: It uses the high-low range to identify trend reversals based on range expansions. It identifies range bulges that can foreshadow a reversal of the current trend.

name: Vortex Indicator (VI)
description: It consists of two oscillators that capture positive and negative trend movement. A bearish signal triggers when the negative trend indicator crosses above the positive trend indicator or a key level.
